data.title: Schwarzenegger leaves complicated legacy
data.meta_description: “It’s a mixed bag.” That’s how Assemblyman Curt Hagman, San Bernardino Mayor Pat Morris and other area leaders described the legacy of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who will l…
data.text:
“It’s a mixed bag.”

That’s how Assemblyman Curt Hagman, San Bernardino Mayor Pat Morris and other area leaders described the legacy of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who will leave office on Monday.

Schwarzenegger, who took the Governor’s Office in a 2003 recall election and was elected to a full term in 2006, came in as a charismatic outsider who wanted to “blow up the boxes” and reshape state government.

He leaves with a 32 percent approval rating and a list of accomplishments that, local leaders say, could have been longer had he done more to convince voters and lawmakers of his vision.

“I worked very hard to get him elected,” said Hagman, R-Chino Hills. “I was really optimistic that as an outsider he would make the drastic changes California needed to do.”

But seven years later, Hagman and others said they are left wanting much more, especially in light of the state’s ongoing financial problems.

Schwarzenegger railed against obscure state boards and commissions, but they remain largely intact.

He continued the political legacy of rewarding termed-out lawmakers by naming them to six-figure jobs on those boards.

He promised to get state government to tighten its belt but used borrowing and accounting gimmicks to close budget deficits.

“I was disappointed – I think a lot of us in California were,” said Assemblyman Paul Cook, R-Yucaipa. “I think we were disappointed because he had enough charisma to make things happen. I expected more.”

Schwarzenegger’s biggest political defeat came in 2005, when voters rejected a slate of Schwarzenegger-backed ballot measures that dealt with budget reform, redistricting, union dues and teacher tenure.

Those measures failed in part, said Assemblywoman Wilmer Amina Carter, D-Rialto, because Schwarzenegger failed to sell them to the public – something he should have been good at.

“I don’t think he articulated to the public how they were going to make a difference,” she said. “He presented it as against groups instead of as for people. … Instead of telling how it would benefit us, we saw it as a battle between two different groups.”

Another part of Schwarzenegger’s failings, said state Sen. Gloria Negrete McLeod, D-Montclair, was that he never forged a meaningful relationship with the state Legislature.

“He came in thinking, `I’m going to go in there and tell everybody how to do stuff,’ but he forget that the governor is not the key,” Negrete McLeod said. “He had to work with the Legislature.”

And some lawmakers say he rarely did that.

“It almost got to the point that we couldn’t talk to his office,” Cook said. “It was a very isolated executive branch that was very cliquish.”

Despite all that, Schwarzenegger does have some accomplishments to his name.

State Sen. Bob Huff, R-Walnut, credited Schwarzenegger with helping to achieve some political reforms, including an independent commission that will redraw boundaries for political districts, and a “top-two” primary system in which the two candidates with the most votes in a primary will face off in the general election – regardless of their political affiliation.

“All in all, I think he did a better job than most people think he did,” Huff said.

Perhaps the most notable legislation signed by Schwarzenegger is Assembly Bill 32, a law aimed at capping the level of greenhouse gas pollution in the state.

It’s a polarizing law – one that put Schwarzenegger, at least for a time, in the good graces of Democrats and environmental groups and forever marked him as a “Republican in Name Only” among conservatives.

“The one area where he did deliver, an area that he stayed committed to, was sustainability and the environment,” said San Bernardino’s Morris. “He believed we should be the vanguard state in sustainability and he helped bring through legislation that made that a reality.”

Morris said he is proud of Schwarzenegger’s stance on A.B. 32 and other environmental issues because it pitted the governor, a Republican, against his own party.

“That put him opposite a lot of conservative members of his lawmaking party,” Morris said. “He would not give way on that. And I’m proud of him for standing his ground.”

Assemblyman Tim Donnelly, R-Claremont, one of San Bernardino County’s two newest lawmakers, said he will remember Schwarzenegger most for A.B. 32.

“Getting the budget under control would have been a great legacy,” Donnelly said. “Instead, his legacy will be A.B. 32. It’s a job killer.”

The Associated Press contributed to this report

Schwarzenegger timeline

Key moments in the governorship of Arnold Schwarzenegger:

August 2003: Schwarzenegger announces on “The Tonight Show with Jay Leno” that he will run for governor.

October 2003: Gray Davis is recalled as governor. Schwarzenegger is elected with nearly 49 percent of the vote.

October 2003: On his first day in office, Schwarzenegger rolls back an increase in the vehicle license fee, fulfilling a campaign promise, costing the state $4 billion in revenue that year.

March 2004: Schwarzenegger wins voter approval of Proposition 57, allowing the state to borrow $15 billion to close its budget deficit, and Proposition 58, allowing the governor to declare a fiscal emergency if a deficit emerges in the middle of a fiscal year.

July 2004: During a budget rally in Ontario, Schwarzenegger calls Democratic legislators “girlie men” because he believes they are led by special interests. The term was lifted from a long-running “Saturday Night Live” skit.

February 2005: Schwarzenegger promotes a plan to cut spending before a giant faucet spewing red-colored water, intended to symbolize red ink.

September 2005: Schwarzenegger vetoes a bill to legalize same-sex marriage, leaving the issue up to voters or the courts.

November 2005: Voters resoundingly reject four initiatives Schwarzenegger placed on the ballot.

November-December 2005: Schwarzenegger replaces most of his inner circle and appoints a Democrat, Susan Kennedy, his chief of staff.

September 2006: Schwarzenegger signs groundbreaking legislation to combat global warming. The law, known as AB32, makes California the first state in the nation to force its major industries to reduce carbon emissions.

November 2006: Schwarzenegger coasts to re-election over state Treasurer Phil Angelides. In addition, Schwarzenegger and lawmakers persuade voters to pass propositions 1B-1E, securing $37.2 billion in bonds for road projects, affordable housing, levees and schools.

January 2007: Schwarzenegger is sworn in to his second term – his first full, four-year term after winning the recall election in 2003.

May 2007: Schwarzenegger signs a $7.8 billion prison-reform plan to add more than 50,000 beds to an overcrowded system.

October 2007: Schwarzenegger vetoes a second bill to legalize same-sex marriage, saying voters and the state Supreme Court should decide the issue.

November 2008: Voters narrowly approve Schwarzenegger’s ballot measure to change how state legislative districts are drawn, giving the job to an independent citizens’ commission.

December 2008: Schwarzenegger orders state workers to take two unpaid days off each month to help ease the state’s budget woes. The furloughs are later extended to three a month.

February 2009: Schwarzenegger and state lawmakers agree to a midyear budget correction to close a deficit estimated at $42 billion over the next 17 months. They cut $15.1 billion, borrow $11.4 billion and raise $12.8 billion by temporarily increasing the state sales and income taxes and vehicle license fee.

June 2010: Voters approve an open primary system championed by Schwarzenegger, who says it will help elect moderate politicians.

October 2010: Schwarzenegger signs the latest state budget after a record 100-day impasse in the Legislature.

November 2010: The Legislative Analyst’s Office says the budget Schwarzenegger signed just weeks before is $6 billion out of balance.

December 2010: Schwarzenegger calls lawmakers into a special session to address the shortfall. Lawmakers meet but defer decisions until after Schwarzenegger’s successor, Jerry Brown, is sworn in.

SOURCE: The Associated Press

“He tried to do what he set out to do, as most of us do as we enter politics. We come in with an idea in mind of how we would like to change the system, but then we run into the system.” – Assemblywoman Wilmer Amina Carter, D-Rialto.

“He’d be the first one to admit he didn’t get as far on these issues as he’d like to, but at least the issues are out there now and people are talking about them.” – Assemblyman Curt Hagman, R-Chino Hills.

“He kept saying, `I’m not a politician.’ Buddy, once you’re elected, you’re a politician.” – State Sen. Gloria Negrete McLeod, D-Montclair.

“I think in four years, he came to our (Assembly Republican) caucus meeting once. The big joke is everybody had to wear name tags … because he didn’t know our names.” – Assemblyman Paul Cook, R-Yucaipa.

“All in all, I think he did a better job than most people think he did,” – State Sen. Bob Huff, R-Walnut.

“As soon as he met some opposition, he just kind of gave up. I think that’s the danger for anyone running on a reform platform. It’s seductive – you want to be liked, you want to be part of the system.” – Assemblyman Tim Donnelly, R-Claremont.

“He stripped our redevelopment – $13 million from San Bernardino. That’s a terrible rip-off of local resources.” – San Bernardino Mayor Pat Morris.
